Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Chemical Mediation of Interactions Between Parasitic Plants and their Hosts
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Chemical Mediation of Interactions between Parasitic Plants and their Hosts

Abstract

This project involves an integrated research and education program centered on the investigation of interactions between parasitic plants in the genus Cuscuta (dodders) and their hosts. The research portion of the project will explore the role of plant volatiles in host-location and host selection by parasitic plants, the defense responses of host plants to parasitism and explore the broader ecological impacts of parasitism for subsequent interactions between plants and other organisms, including pathogens, herbivores and natural enemies. The education portion of the project integrates the proposed research into educational activities including training undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral researchers and the creation of a hands-on learning module for use in a science education course designed to prepare future elementary educators to teach life-science concepts to children. The broader impacts of this integrated research and teaching program include a better understanding of the ecological interactions between parasitic plants and their hosts and the training of students and future educators who have first-hand experience in the conduct of scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the chemical ecology of interactions between parasitic plants and their hosts, including parasite responses to host odors and related issues regarding plant perception of olfactory cues. Plant responses to environmental odors, specifically the damage-induced volatile emissions of neighboring plants under herbivore attack, were first reported more than three decades ago. However, early studies in this area were criticized and the phenomenon of plant olfaction remained controversial until relatively recently. Within the past decade conclusive evidence for plant plant perception of and response to odor cues has come from a number of systems. Our demonstration that parasitic plants in the genus Cuscuta can utilize volatile chemical cues in discriminating among hosts, provided a compelling example of plant olfaction from a novel class of ecological interactions.

In the project supported by this funding, we explored the chemical mediation of interactions among Cuscuta spp., their host plants, and other organisms, as well as broader issues relating to plant responses to environmental odors. Among other findings we characterized the biochemical defense responses of host plants to parasitism by Cuscuta spp. seedlings, including defenses regulated by the jasmonic-acid and salicylic-acid phytohormone pathways, which were each found to mediate effective defenses against parasitism. We compared these defense responses to those induced by other classes of plant antagonists, including insect herbivores and plant-associated microbes, and documented implications for the simultaneous interactions of plants with multiple antagonists in complex ecological environments. In addition, we documented novel aspects of plant responses to environmental odors, including the priming of plant defense responses by olfactory cues, and we showed that within-plant volatile signaling could overcome constraints on the internal transmission of wound signals imposed by the modular architecture of the vascular system. Thus, this work made significant contributions to our knowledge of host-plant interactions with parasitic plants and other antagonists, as well as to our growing understanding of the role of plant olfaction in ecology.

In addition to the knowledge gained, this project also contributed directly to the training of a number of undergraduate, graduate, and post doctoral researchers who participated in this research. A number of high-school students also benefited from this project either by participating directly in research in our laboratory or by developing independent projects with our assistance (two students developed winning science-fair projects based on such projects). This project also served as the basis for a teaching module employed in a course developed to provide hands-on research experience to future science educators. Furthermore, this research and the experimental systems developed were used extensively in educational activities directed at the broader public, including a presentation at the World Science Festival in New York City. Finally, research conducted for this project was featured in a number of documentary film and television features and mentioned in popular science articles published in prominent venues that reach a wide audience.
